description: From Middle English lorel, losel, equivalent to lose +â€Ž -le.

entries.meaning: A good-for-nothing fellow; a vagabond; losel.
examples: But lurco, I apprehend, signifies only a glutton, which falls very short of our idea of a lorel; and besides I do not believe that the word was ever sufficiently common in Latin to give rise to a derivative in English.
